question: Question_10_(b)
statement:
Find the numbers \emph{b},\emph{c} which make the matrix below
diagonalizable. (No need to diagonalize them.)

$\begin{bmatrix}
2 &1 &b &3 \\ 
0 &3 &-1 &c \\ 
0 &0 &2 &2 \\ 
0 &0 &0 &3 
\end{bmatrix}$
sols:
Now let$^{\prime}$s find the eigenvalues of b

$\text{det}(\begin{bmatrix}
2-\lambda &1 &b &3 \\ 
0 &3-\lambda &-1 &c \\ 
0 &0 &2-\lambda &2 \\ 
0 &0 &0 &3-\lambda
\end{bmatrix})=-(\lambda-3)^{2}(\lambda-2)^{2}=0$Solve the equation above to get
$\lambda _{1}=\lambda_{2}=3,\lambda _{3}=\lambda_{4}=2$ As similar to a,
we need to make sure both eigenvalues have exactly 2 corresponding
eigenvectors. When

$\lambda=3,A-\lambda I= \begin{bmatrix}
-1 &1 &b &3 \\ 
0 &0 &-1 &c \\ 
0 &0 &-1 &2 \\
0 &0 &0 &0
\end{bmatrix}$In order to get 2 free variables, we need to set
$\frac{-1}{-1}=\frac{c}{2}$ Thus $c=2$ When

$\lambda=2,A-\lambda I= \begin{bmatrix}
0 &1 &b &3 \\ 
0 &1 &-1 &c \\ 
0 &0 &0 &2 \\
0 &0 &0 &1
\end{bmatrix}$In order to get 2 free variables, we need to set
$\frac{1}{1}=\frac{b}{-1}$ Thus $b=-1$
